body:
@mli 
I run two resnet-50 experiment with different kv-store type and on two machines while other configuration keeps same.
After 30 epochs the one with 'local' gets about 50% while 'device' reaches 65%. 

Could you show me some links to how device works? It feels like has a smaller equivalent learning rate
Thanks, yes, I'll give it a test and try to add an example for image classification

I played with the example scripts before on Windows. It seems like that most of the scripts are Linux oriented. 

I guess you do not have the 'mnist' folder created automatically for the data download. Perhaps you can hack the script a bit (or create 'mnist' folder manually) for it to run in Windows.?
What was the solution? I too would like to write a custom loss function.
Good job on first PR! I'll take a closer look when I get a chance.

If you build with gpu enabled opencv the first gpu memory allocation can be really slow.
All the subsequent ones should be fine.

The temporary solution is to build without opencv or with gpu disabled opencv.

right, you need to tweak it a bit. The script will try to find "mnist"
folder, and if it does not exist, it tries to download one with "wget". But
you know, wget does not exist on windows, thus the problem. You can look
into the script and copy the url of the data. Then use your browser to
download the data, extract it to mnist folder, and then it should run just
fine.

Song Han, Xingyu Liu, Huizi Mao, Jing Pu, Ardavan Pedram, Mark A. Horowitz, William J. Dally, [EIE: Efficient Inference Engine on Compressed Deep Neural Network](http://arxiv.org/pdf/1602.01528v1.pdf)

Thank you! I will test it.

The default gcc in OS X installed by XCode command tool does not OpenMP. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/29057437/compile-openmp-programs-with-gcc-compiler-on-os-x-yosemite

My solution is to install the Intel® Parallel Studio XE Composer and change the compilation flags. https://software.intel.com/en-us/qualify-for-free-software/student

I installed OpenMP with command:  brew install clang-omp
now the warning disappeared, but I still have the same error massage:

  NOTE: a missing vtable usually means the first non-inline virtual member function has no definition.
ld: symbol(s) not found for architecture x86_64
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
make: **\* [bin/im2rec] Error 1
Seems to be OpenCV related, can you provide the detailed log?

Problem solved by editing config.mk like this

export CC = clang-omp
export CXX = clang-omp++
USE_OPENMP = 1

After downloading and installing the mnist dataset manually, it works well right now.
Thanks very much!
Updated.

I think making the metric allow composition would be more elegant. For example, we can use `mx.metric.Accuracy() + mx.metric.MSE()` to generate a new instance of `EvalMetric`. And hence it directly applies for current API.

@piiswrong  @firearasi
I tried to use linear regression to predict Y as a vector (e.g. a coordinate like <123.0,45.0> ) instead of a scalar.
With  symbol.bind() function, I can successfully get some output from the symbol.
However, when I try to build a `mx.model.FeedForward` and feed the train data to it,
it throws the error

`
ValueError: Label must be 1D or 2D (with 2nd dimension being 1)
`

It seems `model.fit` function only support Y which has scalar label instead of `ndarray`. How can I fix it?
The code is given below:

```
def get_symbol2():
    X = mx.symbol.Variable('X')
    M = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=X,num_hidden = 2,name = "M")
    Y = mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(data=M)
    return Y

def work():
    n = 1000
    shape = (n,32,32)
    x = np.random.randint(0,100,shape)
    y = np.random.randint(0,100,(n,2))
    symbol = get_symbol()
    model = mx.model.FeedForward(
        symbol,
        num_epoch=3,
        learning_rate=0.01)

    model.fit(X=x,y = y)

work()


```

I'm hoping this gets added soon as well. For now, without modifying the model code itself, my workaround is to explicitly loop through training epoch by epoch and report performance on various metrics at the end of each epoch.

@Puriney @thirdwing 

In mx.init.Xavier when shape has a length larger than two, fan_in is incorrect because it contains a vector instead of a number and results in an error message: "Error: expecting a single value"
 fan_in should contain the product of the shape elements (except last one), this is what python code uses.
Replacing
fan_in  = shape[-length(shape)]
with
fan_in  = prod(shape[-length(shape)])
solves the issue.

@Sandy4321 ok, I will try my best to add some examples.

you mean you want to fine tune your model with new data?
for example you have trained your model for 10 epoch

```
python my_train.py --network my_retwork -lr 0.1 --num-epoch 10 --model-prefix my_model
```

now you have new dataset, you just need to add a new parameter like this

```
python my_train.py --network my_retwork -lr 0.1 --num-epoch 20 --model-prefix my_model --load-epoch 10
```

`--load-epoch 10` means load the trained model and train for another 20-10 rounds

do not forget to reset the train data path

There is nothing fancy in my kaggle example, it is just a port to R of the python code (which is actually a port from cxxnet) .done by @antinucleon https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/kaggle-ndsb1

See https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1143  (also related is https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/1316)
Use `mxnet.symbol.SliceChannel` to select the part of the weight + grad you want to update, and then do update.

in MXNet it is just not that explicit, it is implicit.
For example, in `softmax_output` layer, the data is just softmax after feedforward, the actually loss is calculated in [metric.py](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/metric.py), when backwarding the gradient is directly calculated by [SoftmaxGrad](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/softmax_output-inl.h#L109) function(you can also write your own codes in backward), so basically speaking, it is the same as implementing new layers.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/1488

Hi,

Installed the GPU enabled R library (R version: 3.2.3) on Windows 7 today. Looks like it's working on the CPU but not on my GPU. The code seems to execute on the GPU (confirmed with GPU-Z), but error improvement stalls on the second round using example code (as above merged issue), and mx.nd.ones(c(2,3), mx.gpu()) generates a table of 0's not 1's.

I'm using the latest files for everything, and the precompiled GPU package for R. I read in this thread: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/250, that indicates 'remove USE_CUDNN' to compile for Cuda Compute GPUs 2.1 (and lower). I'm using a 2.1 GPU. Could this be the problem? 

Could using an earlier 2015 release be a solution? Also might I have to compile my own GPU-enabled files without USE_CUDNN to fix this? I'm hoping I don't have to upgrade my computer to get his working as I'm only doing preliminary testing.

Any help would be appreciated.

Thanks, Gavin.

@juliandewit  The CUDNN is indeterministic, which means the gradient can vary a bit during runs and results in not reproducible weights. However, I feel this can be true for all libraries using CuDNN. 

One way to try is to turn off CuDNN, but I hope the rule won't interpret in that way :)  and the good model architecture and similar results should mean reproducibility


The output of `infer_shape` does not contain the symbols names. We need something like `symbol.get_name()` and `symbol.get_output_shape(symbol_name)`. More generally, how to directly get the information of a non-terminal symbol?
`
([(1L, 3L, 299L, 299L), (32L, 3L, 3L, 3L), (32L,), (32L,), (32L, 32L, 3L, 3L), (32L,), (32L,), (64L, 32L, 3L, 3L), (64L,), (64L,), (96L, 64L, 3L, 3L), (96L,), (96L,), (64L, 160L, 1L, 1L), (64L,), (64L,), (64L, 64L, 7L, 1L), (64L,), (64L,), (64L, 64L, 1L, 7L), (64L,), (64L,), (96L, 64L, 3L, 3L), (96L,), (96L,)], [(1L, 96L, 65L, 65L)], [(32L,), (32L,), (32L,), (32L,), (64L,), (64L,), (96L,), (96L,), (64L,), (64L,), (64L,), (64L,), (64L,), (64L,), (96L,), (96L,)])
`
`pprint.pprint` the above output shows that the second element is the symbol's output shape.

Using `Flatten` in the last layers avoids the error.

```
  pool = mx.sym.Pooling(data = data, kernel = (8, 8), stride = (1, 1), pool_type = 'avg', name = 'global_pool')
  flatten = mx.sym.Flatten(data = pool, name = 'flatten')
  dropout = mx.symbol.Dropout(data = flatten, p = 0.2, name = 'dropout')
  fc1 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = dropout, num_hidden = num_classes, name = 'fc1')
  softmax = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data = fc1, name = 'softmax')
```

Hello I rebuilt it without cudnn.
It cost me my last hairs but in the end it was all quite doable.. :)
The 1st epoch gives exactly the same results between runs so I think I'm good.

So thanks again for this great framework esp for targetting so many platforms. 
The prebuilt binaries etc are golden.

Perhaps after this comp is done I can make a contribution to your examples directory of my solution.

Got it. The right call is
`concat = mxnet:::mx.varg.symbol.Concat(con)`
Let's keep this open since I think it is misleading and I need to change it.
cool! good luck on the comp!
